en-US.title: One Year of Restaking: The "Double-Edged Sword" Effect on Ethereum Security
en-US.content:
Friends, today we're diving deep into an important innovation that's reshaping Ethereum's economic model: restaking. After more than a year of development, this concept has evolved from an experimental idea into critical infrastructure managing tens of billions of dollars in assets.

Let me first explain what restaking is. Imagine you mortgage your house to a bank for a car loan, then use that car loan as collateral to apply for a credit card. Restaking works on a similar principle: you use the same batch of ETH to simultaneously provide security guarantees for both Ethereum mainnet and other services, earning multiple rewards while also taking on multiple risks.

This seemingly complex financial innovation solves a fundamental problem: how do new blockchain services obtain sufficient security? Previously, each new project had to issue its own tokens and build its own validator network, which was costly and inefficient. Now, they can "rent" Ethereum's security.

Data shows that restaking protocols currently have over $15 billion worth of ETH locked up, equivalent to about 15% of Ethereum's total staked amount. EigenLayer, as the leading protocol, already supports dozens of different services, from decentralized oracles to cross-chain bridges, from data availability layers to decentralized sequencers.

This innovation has brought significant yield improvements. Regular ETH staking yields about 3-4% annually, while users participating in restaking can earn 6-8% or even higher returns. For large institutions, this additional yield is extremely attractive.

But every coin has two sides. The risks of restaking are also accumulating. If a service experiences serious failures or attacks, the ETH participating in restaking could face massive slashing. Even more concerning, if multiple services encounter problems simultaneously, it could trigger a chain reaction threatening the stability of the entire Ethereum network.

From a market performance perspective, restaking has become the new "benchmark" for DeFi yields. Many traditional liquidity mining projects find it difficult to attract funds if their yields are lower than restaking. This "yield arms race" is redefining DeFi's risk-return structure.

The deeper impact lies in governance. Large amounts of ETH concentrated in a few restaking protocols could affect Ethereum's degree of decentralization. If these protocol operators make poor decisions, the impact would extend far beyond individual projects.

Technical innovations continue as well. The latest restaking protocols are introducing "risk tiering" mechanisms, allowing users to choose service combinations with different risk levels. Some protocols are also exploring "insurance" mechanisms to provide additional risk protection for restakers.

Looking long-term, restaking might spawn an entirely new "security market." Services with different risk levels will have different "security pricing," forming a more refined risk management system.

This innovation reminds us that while pursuing higher yields, we cannot ignore the accumulation of systemic risks. Restaking is both a manifestation of Ethereum ecosystem prosperity and a potential risk point we need to continuously monitor. Wise investors will find balance between opportunity and risk.
